title: Sustainability Goals in TÃ¼rkiye: Energy, Emissions, and the Future
text:
2.2 General Information About Data
The data obtained from TÃœÄ°K provide information on the sectoral distribution of carbon emissions in TÃ¼rkiye over the years, as well as GDP figures necessary for calculating energy intensity. Additionally, the data gathered from the IEA include TÃ¼rkiyeâ€™s total primary energy supply, annual energy amounts by source, energy-related carbon emissions, the carbon intensity of the energy mix, per capita carbon emissions, electricity generation and consumption figures, and the share of renewable energy sources in electricity generation.

title: Sustainability Goals in TÃ¼rkiye: Energy, Emissions, and the Future
text:
2.3 Reason of Choice
This study has been selected with the aim of contributing to sustainable development goals in line with energy and climate policies.
In order to shed light on the extent to which carbon-free growth is achievable and how Turkeyâ€™s trends over the years align with these goals, this topic has been chosen from the perspectives of energy, environment, and society, particularly given that energy-related emissions constitute a major portion of global warming.
Raising awareness on this issue is also one of the primary motivations behind the study.

title: Assignment 1
section: (c) Displaying and Handling the â€œna_exampleâ€ Dataset
text:
(c) Displaying and Handling the â€œna_exampleâ€ Dataset

library(dslabs)

Warning: package 'dslabs' was built under R version 4.4.3

data(na_example)


str(na_example)

 int [1:1000] 2 1 3 2 1 3 1 4 3 2 ...



NA_count <- sum(is.na(na_example))
cat("Total Number of NAs:", NA_count)

Total Number of NAs: 145

NA_index_pos <- which(is.na(na_example))
cat("Index positions of NAs:", NA_index_pos) 

Index positions of NAs: 12 17 27 50 51 52 59 65 66 68 91 117 125 126 127 128 139 140 141 142 153 158 168 169 172 179 189 190 203 205 207 208 212 214 237 241 243 244 253 257 265 267 269 279 282 287 290 298 310 325 326 330 341 348 361 374 392 395 397 407 410 437 443 446 461 468 470 490 496 505 527 536 539 553 561 576 578 589 599 603 609 616 618 620 630 633 636 641 652 653 666 667 668 677 680 687 691 695 701 726 734 735 736 745 746 747 748 751 756 762 767 788 789 807 821 826 832 838 843 844 845 849 850 853 859 869 887 892 893 906 909 911 918 924 925 939 943 950 962 965 966 968 979 990 999



cat("Mean:", mean(na_example,na.rm=TRUE), "Std_dev:", sd(na_example,na.rm=TRUE))

Mean: 2.301754 Std_dev: 1.22338



replace_median <- ifelse(is.na(na_example), median(na_example, na.rm = TRUE), na_example)
cat("version 1 (replaced with median):","\n","Mean:", mean(replace_median), "Std_dev:", sd(replace_median))

version 1 (replaced with median): 
 Mean: 2.258 Std_dev: 1.136102



replace_random<- ifelse(is.na(na_example), sample(na_example[!is.na(na_example)],replace = TRUE), na_example)
cat("version 2 (replaced with random_v):","\n","Mean:", mean(replace_random),"Std_dev:", sd(replace_random))

version 2 (replaced with random_v): 
 Mean: 2.3 Std_dev: 1.222086


The median replacement method is better because it is not affected by outliers and keeps the dataset stable. Random replacement adds variability, which can distort the data.

title: Assignment 1
section: (a) A Brief Summary about â€œVeri Bilimi ve EndÃ¼stri MÃ¼hendisliÄŸi Ãœzerine Sohbetler - Cem Vardar&Erdi DaÅŸdemirâ€
text:
(a) A Brief Summary about â€œVeri Bilimi ve EndÃ¼stri MÃ¼hendisliÄŸi Ãœzerine Sohbetler - Cem Vardar&Erdi DaÅŸdemirâ€
Cem Vardar mentioned the role of industrial engineering in problem-solving processes within complex systems, emphasizing that even complex problems can be solved by starting from simple ones. He stated that data science is a tool in problem-solving, particularly used in improving complex systems. He highlighted the importance of soft skills such as analytical thinking, problem-solving, curiosity, and the ability to establish cause-and-effect relationships. As for technical skills, he stated that probability, statistics, programming, data collection, processing, and visualization are fundamental, and the ability to model develops when it is specialized in the business context.
Lastly, he emphasized the importance of learning general skills such as problem-solving, working with data, understanding data, taking a holistic approach, thinking multidimensionally, and having the ability to learn. He suggested focusing on the problem rather than the tools, the significance of mental models, the Pareto principle, approaching problems through inversion, understanding game theory, and the value of readings.
